chapter.title: Introduction to Linux Containers
chapter.para: Linux containers are a lightweight virtualization method to run multiple virtual units (containers) simultaneously on a single host. This is similar to the environment. Containers are isolated with kernel Control Groups () and kernel Namespaces.

Containers provide virtualization on the operating system level where the kernel controls the isolated containers. This is unlike full virtualization solutions like &xen; or &kvm; where the processor simulates a complete hardware environment and controls s.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: Conceptually, container can be seen as an improved technique. The difference is that a environment separates only the file system, whereas container goes further and provides resource management and control via .
